' Thinking like this for a short while, he then focused his attention on listening to the sounds of singing and so forth.

Those heavenly maidens each obtain the night-shining god to enjoy desires together with them, and their minds think like this:
'The king only loves me and does not love the others.

The desires of the night-shining gods are accomplished by verbal expression, without physical union.

At that time, the newly born god again approached the night-shining god, the night-shining king, and saw that he was surrounded by countless hundreds of thousands of heavenly multitudes, with countless kinds of fully perfected supreme virtues, with a tongue that subdued the heavenly multitudes.
The night-shining god SuyÄma knows all the gods, whether born before or just born.
SuyÄma sees the newly born god, his eyes do not move, the other old gods then tell the newly born god, saying these words:
'Great King, now you look like this, why don't you kneel?'

At that time, King SuyÄma, seeing him kneel, said:
'Great Sage!
You are now born in the heaven of YÄma.
You are now in the first place of bliss in the heaven of YÄma, where you will experience bliss.
You have attained rebirth here by cultivating the three kinds of good deeds. You have come here well.
Because of your good karma, you will experience bliss here, staying in this heavenly realm for a long time. Do not act with heedlessness.'
The god-king Muá¹£itasmá¹›ti then spoke a verse to the newly born god:
The newly born god, if you love the pleasures of this life,
They are not worth a sixteenth part of the suffering of falling back.
Little taste, much fear, always deceiving and deluding men,
Like a city of gandharvas, the taste of sensual pleasures is also like this.
These desires are extremely evil, able to destroy sentient beings,
Therefore, the wise one always does not believe in desires in his mind.'
The god-king Muá¹£itasmá¹›ti thus taught the newly born god, and the newly born god thus addressed the god-king Muá¹£itasmá¹›ti, saying:
It is true, god-king!
I did not know that there are such faults in this heaven, and I did not know how to practice the Dharma in the heavens.
Just as other gods act, I act in the same way. I do not know myself.'
At that time, King of the Heaven Muzhou Lou Tuo spoke a verse, saying:
If death arrives, there is no other companion,
After death, going to a different place, there is no one who goes together.
The minds of sentient beings are various, with many kinds of mental inclinations,
Thus, with various karmas, they create the bondage of birth and death.
Until the moment of birth, it is certain that one belongs to death,
Various delusions cover the mind, not knowing the fear of this.
If the time of decline has arrived, it can destroy the first existence,
That deluded mind does not realize the fear of the suffering of death.
Joyfully giving rise to carelessness, repeatedly experiencing birth and death,
The deluded one does not realize that the realms can deceive the gods.
The snake of objects can bite, and objects give rise to the delusion of love,
The gods are always unaware, and when they fall, there is great fear.
The suffering of birth is the greatest, and there is no such suffering in falling,
Such great suffering of birth is only accomplished in the heavens.
Blown by the wind of karma, one transmigrates and experiences great suffering,
What a man dies with, his mind is deceived and not in control.
Neither father nor mother, nor friends nor relatives,
When the time of death arrives, there is no companion.
By nature, it deceives like this, and no one has a companion,
Only the mind is so evil, each deceiving the other.
No one else, nor even relatives, can be a savior,
When the time of death arrives, relatives are also like non-relatives.
If you see a non-relative, you will also experience great joy,
The power of the king of death is sovereign, and he forcibly takes away great joy.
The objects of the senses cause the mind to be deluded, and one is always controlled by desire.
Although one may not yet experience suffering and distress, one will definitely experience it, there is no doubt.
' The god-king of the Heaven of YÄma, Muá¹£itasmá¹›ti, teaches the newly born gods with such true principles.
When the newly born gods hear this, they feel aversion;
but in an instant, they again sing, dance, play, laugh, and become attached again.
The minds of all foolish ordinary beings in the world are impermanent, unstable, and their minds are covered by the power of pleasure. Controlled by craving, their minds move a hundred times more.
For this reason, the gods indulge in carelessness.
For this reason, not even a little dharma abides in their minds.

At that time, the newly born celestial being, in the palace of the celestial king Musulunda, with various amusements, singing and dancing with his own retinue, engaged in various playful activities, possessing all the five kinds of sensual pleasures.
Experiencing the pleasures of the realm, gathering together and returning, following the path he came, to his own abode.
Wandering in the clouds, to his original dwelling place.
Having returned, he again enjoys various pleasures with the other celestial beings, playfully wandering towards the hall called Vast.
That hall is lovely, now I will fully describe it.
Inside there are twenty nayutas of houses, with various colors, different shapes and forms, and a gathering of precious lights, with many celestial beings and celestial maidens.
Such a wonderful hall, all that the celestial being thinks of, he obtains.
As the celestial being thinks in his mind, he obtains all such forms and such shapes.
The gardens, forests, and flower ponds are adorned with countless hundreds of thousands of birds. The seven-jeweled mountain peaks
are like this due to the good karmic actions of the devas.
If the devas recollect and wish to travel, the palace together with the gardens, forests, lotus ponds, and various heavenly trees fly through the sky, no different from birds.
If the devas recollect:
If this palace moves, I will experience pleasure,
then at the moment of recollection, they fly away.
If the devas recollect and give rise to this thought:
Whatever I need, food and drink are complete,
then there will be rivers of flowing heavenly food, with countless varieties all complete, appearing according to recollection, with perfect color, aroma, and flavor filling the flowing rivers.
Due to the good karmic actions of those sons of the devas, if there were unwholesome karmic actions, there would be no such realms.
Moreover, these devas give rise to this thought:
'Within this palace of mine, it becomes even more spacious, a hundred yojanas wide.'

At the moment of thought, there are often countless kinds of delightful flowing streams, ponds with beautiful lotus flowers, and valleys, fully equipped with dwellings, various gardens, forests, and beautiful lotus flowers, all complete.
In this way, it is vast. The gods, having seen this, become even more joyful and give rise to this thought:
'I will roam and play in this place, my mind joyful, and I will enjoy pleasures here with other gods.
I will also cause other gods to enjoy pleasures together with me in this palace, and if the king of the YÄma gods and his heavenly multitudes come here, I will enjoy pleasures with them.'
At the moment the god gives rise to this thought, the heavenly multitudes of the YÄma Heaven King Muá¹£itasmá¹›ti will go to his palace to play together.
At the moment of thought, the gods will set out:
Some rode on geese, some on peacocks, some on other birds, some on flowers, some on ducks, some on mandarin ducks, some on avadavats, and some on trees.

They came riding on various vehicles, with joyful and delighted minds, playing music, and together with various celestial maidens adorned with different forms and garments, laughing, singing, and dancing, with beautiful lotus garlands draped over their bodies, experiencing the utmost bliss.
With joyful and delighted minds, praised by the celestial maidens, they traveled through the sky towards the celestial pleasure palaces.
Having arrived, they mutually enjoyed various pleasures, and due to such indulgent and heedless conduct, their minds became unstable.
The YÄma Heaven King MothushrÄ« saw their heedlessness and observed them.
Like the heedless gods, he observed their heedless conduct.
He gave rise to this thought:
'What expedient means can I use to benefit and bring peace and happiness to such careless gods?'
At that time, King Muzhoulou further thought with a subtle mind:
'Now I will let other gods who are srota-Äpannas follow me and discuss matters together.
In that place - in the midst of the place where the clouds roam, various pleasures are enjoyed and one indulges in carelessness. How can the good Dharma be used to guide those gods?
Benefit oneself and others, doing both for each other, causing both myself and others to be free from faults.
I am a good friend, causing them to benefit. Expounding the Dharma to benefit others is a good teacher.
If one teaches evil karma, then one is an enemy, able to cause the gathering of the evil karma of hell.

At that time, King of the Heaven of the Thirty-three and the stream-enterer, having deliberated, transformed a wondrous palace through their own spiritual powers and ascended that palace together, heading towards it.
The first river and pond are replete with flowing water, and the gardens and groves are all fully endowed, with countless kinds of things that are all delightful.
There are such supreme and wondrous things, all heading towards that place.
The palace that moves through the clouds and wanders in the sky is then inferior, a hundred times inferior, a thousand times inferior.
Why is this?
Because of the power of good karma, in the Heaven of YÄma, all the good karma of the gods in the Heaven of YÄma, the good karma of King of the Heaven of YÄma is supreme.
For those with superior good karma, their spiritual powers are also superior.
For this reason, their palace is superior, with wondrous light surpassing all the palaces of the gods in the Heaven of YÄma.
It is like the palace of the sun, which none of the other palaces can compare to even slightly.
In this way, that palace is the most supreme, and the palaces of the other gods cannot compare to even a small portion of it.

That palace, with its own merits fully endowed, travels through the sky towards that place of pleasure where the gods roam and enjoy themselves like clouds, and the gods of the stream-enterers follow together.
Because the gods of the stream-enterers, the noble ones, have little indulgence in carelessness, they therefore follow together towards that place.

At that time, the gods who indulge in carelessness, having seen King Muá¹£itasmá¹›ti, gave rise to a respectful mind and quickly advanced, all of them going to welcome King Muá¹£itasmá¹›ti of the YÄma Heaven.

At that time, King Muá¹£itasmá¹›ti, having arrived at that palace, immediately manifested his spiritual powers and through his transformative abilities caused the welcoming gods to suddenly no longer see each other, only seeing themselves alone approaching the heavenly king;
They could not hear any of the delightful sounds and could not see any of the various wondrous forms.
Because of the king's spiritual powers, he caused each of those gods to have this thought:

They always sit in this palace with me. Where have they all gone now that I cannot see them?
Having thought this, those gods each went before King Muá¹£itasmrti.
They only saw the king and the srota-Äpanna, but did not see the others.
All the gods each gave rise to a rare thought, their minds filled with fear. They all said to King Muá¹£itasmrti,
'The gods who dwell in this palace of ours, we do not know where they have gone now.'
At that time, King Muá¹£itasmrti said to those gods:

'Thus, all these gods are indulging in all kinds of pleasures, engaging in wanton conduct. Due to the exhaustion of their karma, they will fall into hell, the realm of hungry ghosts, or the animal realm, or be reborn among humans.
If the gods who are indulging in pleasures engage in wanton conduct, they will be destroyed by wantonness and ruined by the love of sense objects.

Because their minds delight in the merits of the five desires, their minds burn with the fire of sense objects, thinking and discriminating. This blazing fire arises from the flint of their own minds.

Blown by the wind of karma, in the hall called Vast, their minds are not content, and after being burned by the five flames of fire, they are again burned by the great fire of hell, experiencing various sufferings.
Deceived by their own minds, when their bodies perish and their lives end, they are reborn in hell.
This fault of wantonness is the most supreme among all faults.
Why is it so?
Because those who are destroyed by the fault of wantonness lose all good dharmas.

In this way, the foolish gods will later regret it.'
At that time, all the gods there, having heard this from King Muá¹£itasmrti, each gave rise to disgust and fear in their minds. They said to King Muá¹£itasmrti, 'King of the gods, great king!

All the gods in just a moment are like this, declining, and the place where the clouds roam is completely empty.
What expedient means can we use to prevent us from declining?
To not experience suffering and separation, to not experience the suffering of separation?
To not fall into the realms of hell, hungry ghosts, or animals?'
At that time, King Muá¹£itasmrti spoke a verse to those gods:
Those who engage in the path of heedlessness do not see what is virtuous,

Apart from causes there are no effects, without causes and effects one cannot obtain,

Heedlessness destroys life, thus the gods transmigrate,
That delusion loses good karma, and falls into the realms of evil paths.
If there is this deluded mind, enjoying the pleasures of desire,

Those burned by the fire of desire, deceived by objects,
Do not obtain the path of tranquility, all the supreme bliss.
If it is the pleasures of desire in the world, or the bliss born from love,

Tranquility is foremost, the white dharmas leave birth and death,
The foremost bliss is the exhaustion of craving, the bliss of ultimate non-retrogression.
The contented one who is not afraid, the practitioner who does not seek,
Such is the bliss of meditative concentration, there is no bliss comparable to it.
If one is not bound by craving, not destroyed by doubt,
Then one will cross the ocean of existence and always experience all bliss.
If the mind dwells in desire, then one will not experience bliss,
This is the vessel of all suffering, entering the realm of hell.
Constantly bound by the fetters of karma, being dragged along by it,
There is no one who can save and deliver one from this suffering.
The seen past and future dharmas, due to karma there is birth and death,
The past and future are all like this, obtained through the causes of karma.
Out of foolishness one craves desire, even until the time of death,
Experiencing the great suffering of birth and death, yet unable to be aware of it.
Because of being covered by delusion, one experiences pleasure without being content;
Because of being insatiable, one is thus always destroyed.
Not at the beginning, not in the middle, not at the end, not now, not in future lives,
Those who always cultivate desires, due to ignorance, revolve [in samsara].
Because of the exhaustion of good karma, one will certainly fall from this place;
Those who eat the poison of indulgence, due to delusion, do not realize it.
This body changes moment by moment, but due to delusion one does not realize it;
Only when one is about to fall in the future does one realize the suffering and distress.ğŸ”½If one is afraid of suffering,
and afraid of death,
One should contemplate the true Dharma, and thus one will surely attain happiness.'
At that time, the gods, having heard what the Heavenly King Muzhoulou had said, temporarily became free from their indulgent thoughts. They then addressed the Heavenly King Muzhoulou, saying:
'Heavenly King, Great King!
All the gods cannot see it at all. Could it have been destroyed in an instant?
Is it all lost?

At that time, King Muzhouluo said to them:
'The good karma of the Tathagata has also gone like this.
Because the karma is exhausted, all karmic dharmas are definitely like this.

All sentient beings separate from each other, and their minds are filled with distress. Old age, sickness, and death - these three kinds of opposing dharmas of existence - have little life and no sickness.
If a man - whether human or heavenly - is not heedless, and does not act heedlessly, he will be able to perceive these three kinds of fear.
Because of heedlessness, these three kinds - having little life and no sickness - will all be lost. All the gods are definitely like this, until death comes.
They diligently practice and make various skillful means, with three kinds of diligence: giving, precepts, and wisdom. These three can remove these three great fears.

Countless thoughts always follow one's actions, temporarily not leaving. If one is not afraid, then later when one is about to die, one's mouth and face are broken, one's eyes roll around, one's faculties are dry, and all one's relatives, brothers, wives, children, and family members abandon one. At that time, one is burned by the fire of separation from what one loves, and one dies in extreme pain.

Those gods at all times have countless thoughts, and the five desires are present. They sing, dance, play, laugh, rejoice, and roam about. In the gardens and forests, they experience such pleasures and indulge in objects.
Just as one sees the faces of good friends and acquaintances, but does not realize their consequences, later one is burned by the fire of regret.
Why did I not do good deeds?
Why did I not give?
Why did I not keep the precepts?
Why did I not cultivate wisdom?
Why did I not do these three things?
Because of negligence, I am now alone and dying, separated from my relatives and brothers, and am being taken away by death.
I am being led away from this world's most beloved place, where I enjoyed immeasurable pleasures.
In this way, later on, the mind gives rise to regret and remorse, and in this way, it can destroy the gods.
Before the powerful King of Death arrives, you must absolutely not be negligent.
By abandoning negligence, you will certainly attain peace and, when you die, will not be burned by the fire of regret. This path is the most peaceful.

All those who are in decline and distress, who delight in giving, morality, and wisdom, and who practice them a lot, will at that time be saved and liberated by relying on them. They are the support, the savior, and the powerful companion.
'When death arrives, it is certain that one cannot escape and it will definitely destroy you.
When it comes, it cannot be stopped, avoided, or escaped, and it can take away the lives of all beings.
Why not diligently practice with skillful means to prevent it from coming?
All carelessness and evil are very wise before they arrive.
Like a great poisonous fire, carelessness is also like this.
You gods are controlled by carelessness.
Moreover, all gods belong to carelessness, and that enemy of carelessness follows without letting go.

In the gardens, forests, mountains, and peaks, while playing and roaming, all phenomena are impermanent but you think they are permanent, giving rise to this thought:ğŸ”½I will always be with those celestial maidens, enjoying pleasures together. The celestial maidens are always young and do not age.
These celestial maidens will always be with me, and I will never be separated from them.
In this way, they are always deceived by the pleasures of the sense objects, which have the greatest power to destroy.
When the king of death arrives, the celestial maidens cannot stop him or save him, nor can the mind of reflection save him;
The mind of constant discrimination also cannot save him.
All that he thinks is empty, impermanent, unstable, and unreliable. Having been destroyed by carelessness, he will be born in hell, as a hungry ghost, or as an animal.
Destroyed by delusion, he will suffer greatly.
Moreover, those gods, revolving in birth and death since beginningless time, repeatedly grieve and are always deceived, yet foolishly do not realize it.
At that time, the lord of the gods, Muzhoulou Tuo, spoke words in accord with the Dharma and meaning, saying this.
If the gods there are wise, they will take in their minds those words like nectar, pure and stainless, and abandon carelessness, deeply disliking desire.
Having thus correctly remembered in their minds, the gods will speak in verse to King Muá¹£itasmá¹›ti:
If there is benefit and truth, in accord with reality and without contradiction,
The gods speak in this way, which is the cause of benefit.
Able to gather the mind in tranquility, such a one will attain happiness,
From happiness to a place of happiness, one will certainly attain happiness without doubt.
If one is deluded about this, careless and destroyed by the gods,
Such a deluded mind will certainly fall into hell.
Having thus spoken to the king of the gods, the gods will give rise to a mind of disgust.
The gods will then ask the king of the gods again:
We now have doubts.
Where have all the heavenly beings in this palace gone?'

At that time, King of the Heaven of Joy, having seen their subjugation and the arising of disgust in their minds, and having already abandoned their heedlessness, withdrew his spiritual powers, and the heavenly beings saw each other again.
Having seen each other, they gave rise to joyful minds toward each other.
Having given rise to joy in their minds, King of the Heaven of Joy said to them:
'You were each obstructed from seeing each other. Previously, it was because of my spiritual powers that you were obstructed from seeing each other.
Now you have seen each other again as before.

If the powerful king of death, who can destroy, comes here, you will never see each other for hundreds of thousands of koá¹­is of kalpas, and you will fall into the hells, hungry ghosts, or animals, and will never be able to see each other again like this.
Therefore, you should remember not to be negligent, do not give rise to different thoughts, always keep your mind focused, and do not delight in objects.
At that time, many gods, having heard this, give rise to extreme disgust.
Because their minds are disgusted, they attain the stage of stream-entry.
At that time, the heavenly king Muzhoulou, having understood this, is extremely joyful and gives rise to this thought:
'I have accomplished what I needed to do now, my own mind is satisfied, I will leave this place and go to the place of play.'
The assembly of gods who roam in the clouds, with the foremost good mind, if there are those who have already attained stream-entry, they practice without negligence.
If there are those who have not attained it, their minds are then light, they still practice with negligence, delight in negligent conduct, and delight in the pleasures of negligence.

In this way, together with the celestial maidens, they experience various pleasures in the gardens, forests, flowing streams, ponds, mountain peaks, and valleys, not fearing death, until they reach that place to experience pleasure, play, sing, dance, and laugh. The delightful and wholesome karma they accumulated is all exhausted.
When wholesome karma is exhausted, they do nothing that should be done, and fall again into hell, hungry ghosts, or animals.

If there is remaining karma, they are born among humans, always at all times with the greatest joy and pleasure, the most upright, and endowed with the greatest wealth, loved by all people, with a joyful nature and mind, following the practice of the Dharma, experiencing pleasure through play, singing, and dancing, delighting in going to monasteries, with lotus ponds, flowing streams, and ponds.

If a king, minister, or wealthy person has good relations with all their acquaintances, loves and cherishes their relatives and siblings, never speaks falsely, always has an upright mind, always enjoys associating with good people, does not violate propriety, and is endowed with immeasurable merits,
such a person's body will be complete, and they will obtain such a body due to other karmic causes.
Furthermore, the bhiká¹£us know the fruits of karma and observe the abodes of the Heaven of YÄma.
They see, hear, and know:
In the Heaven of YÄma there is another place called Accumulated Burdens.
What karma do sentient beings have to be born in that place?
They see, hear, and know:

If a good man always fears the fruits of karma, has an upright nature, right views, and does not go astray, practices right actions, abandons bad friends, always remembers the Buddha, Dharma, and Saá¹ƒgha at all times, deeply fears even the slightest bad karma, does not kill, steal, or engage in sexual misconduct, and so forth, even when traveling,

If they see women singing, dancing, or adorned with ornaments, they do not become attached, do not cherish them in their minds, observe them well with their minds, have no unwholesome thoughts, and do not delight in them. Having seen their faults, they do not discriminate.

If they do not give rise to wrong conduct in this way, when their body perishes and their life ends, they will be reborn in a good realmâ€”in the Heaven of YÄma, in the place called Accumulated Hardships.
â€œThose who have done good deeds and are reborn there will experience uninterrupted bliss, always endowed with their own radiance, and will enjoy the pleasures of the five senses.
There is a mountain called Accumulated Cliff, adorned with trees of the seven precious substances, filling that mountain.
There are countless hundreds of thousands of various birds, with countless wonderful colors adorning that mountain. The various sounds they emit in that mountain are delightful to see.
There are many kinds of wonderful colors, various places and activities, and countless shapes filling the mountains.

There are also flowing streams, ponds, various lotus flowers, and valleys with many kinds of trees called mindful trees as adornments, with branches intertwined to form houses, and various flowers and fruits all complete.
The size of the mountain is three hundred yojanas, and the multitudes of gods and goddesses are abundant everywhere, all delightful in the mountains.
It is the dwelling place of the first group of gods.
In this way, in the various parts of the mountain, in all the good places, the seven peaks and seven sides are all adorned with gardens and forests of various kinds.
In that good place there are seven kinds of jewels, each of which forms one side.
The light of one side, the blue jewel, extends to sixty thousand yojanas, and such light universally fills the sky with blue color.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:

If the gods remember and wish to ascend the mountain, the gods themselves will adorn their bodies with various jewels, walk on the mountain of accumulated cliffs, and fly through the sky on the blue jewel side.
The various jewels that adorn the gods' bodies have no light or color, but the same color as the mountain, all becoming blue in color and blue light, equal to the mountain.
The blue color and blue light are all supreme.
The mountain of accumulated cliffs has such a blue jewel color on one side.

Moreover, on the second side of the mountain of accumulated cliffs, it is all crystal. If the gods adorn their bodies in various ways, walking on that side with various patterns, flying through the sky, the various jewels that adorn the body have no light or color, but the same color as the mountain, namely the color of crystal.
The light is also like that, equal to the mountain.
The light of the gods' bodies is like entering a pond.
